item.title: Asymmetric Encryption
item.description:
What Is Asymmetric Encryption? #

Asymmetric encryption, also known as public-key encryption, is a method of encrypting data that involves two separate keys: a public key and a private key. These keys are mathematically linked but not identical, hence the term “asymmetric.” This method provides a secure way of encrypting and decrypting information, and it’s widely used in various forms of digital communication and security protocols

How Does It Work? #

Key Generation: #

A pair of cryptographic keys is generated. The process involves complex algorithms like RSA or ECC, ensuring that these keys are mathematically linked. The public key is designed to be shared, while the private key is kept confidential by the owner.

TLS (Transport Layer Security) and its predecessor, SSL (Secure Sockets Layer), are integral to HTTPS, which stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure. item.title: TLS Handshake: Certificate
item.description:
TLS Handshake: Certificate #

What is a TLS Certificate? #

During the TLS handshake, the server sends its certificate to the client to prove its identity. This certificate contains the server‚Äôs public key and information about who issued the certificate (a Certificate Authority). The client uses this certificate to verify that it’s really talking to the correct server, and then uses the public key to help create a secure, encrypted connection.

item.title: TLS Handshake: Certificate Verify
item.description:
TLS Handshake: Certificate Verify #

What is CertificateVerify? #

During the TLS handshake, the server sends a CertificateVerify message to prove it owns the private key corresponding to the public key in its certificate. This step prevents attackers from using a stolen certificate without having the private key.

What Happens in This Step? #

  1. The server creates a hash of all previous handshake messages (called the “handshake transcript”).
  2. The server signs this hash using its private key.
  3. The server sends the CertificateVerify message to the client. It includes:
    • The signature algorithm used (e.g., sha256+rsa_pss_rsae)
    • The digital signature value

item.description:
TLS Handshake: Finished #

What is the Finished Message? #

After the client verifies the server‚Äôs identity (with CertificateVerify), both the client and server send a Finished message. This message is the final step in the handshake that proves everything up to this point has not been tampered with.

Purpose #

The Finished message ensures that:

  • All previous handshake steps were received and processed correctly.
  • The handshake wasn’t modified or intercepted by an attacker.
  • Both parties derived the same symmetric encryption key.
